title: Pacific Maritime Big Book of Bees
text:
Observation notes
Bee pages have notes on historical observations curated from literature. See our references page for a complete list of sources.
An observation note is formatted as follows: Author et al., date of publication: (Name of observer), date collected, location collected. For example:

Guzman et al., 2023: (Gielens), 2010, Vancouver Island

title: News
text:
More new bees for 2025! 🐝






 Bee Book recognized



Our efforts have been recognized by the Native Bee Society of BC with the 2025 certificate of appreciation for data management 🎉 thanks all!



Bee book has been used for the City of North Vancouver annual report by the Native Bee Society of BC
Our melittologist friends are using the Bee Book to decide where to look for bees to document
We used the Bee Book to prepare the Bee Atlas annual summary
New updates to introduction and general info on the Bee Book site
3rd edition data release

















GBIF doi
Bee book data
Code release




Bee book gallery shows two pieces of information per species page:

Bee image (curated by KQ)
Map of observations in Pacific Maritime (pulled from GBIF)

Page completeness is as follows:

title: Xylocopa varipuncta
text:
Observation notes
OSU Insect Collection: 1949, Capilano Canyon. Note: this was likely a failed introduction of the species and that if the record is valid, that it has not established or been detected since. It is a more southern species, which at this time, does not survive outside of the central valley of California.

text:
Observation notes

title: Bombus vosnesenskii
text: ©️ Thomas Barbin.

title: Bombus vosnesenskii
text:
Observation notes
Lutz and Cockerell 1920: Vancouver Island. Muesebeck et al. 1951: Pacific coast. Tommasi et al. 2004: Greater Vancouver Area. Ratti et al. 2008: Fraser Valley. Fraser et al. 2012: E. L. C. Ratti, 2004, numerous localities recorded for the Lower Mainland and adjacent Vancouver Island, Cowichan Lake Forestry Station; Abbotsford; Fraser Valley Regional District, Onnink property. Biodiversity Galiano Life List: 2017, Galiano. Guzman et al., 2023: 2007; 2009, 2010; 2012; 2014, 2015; 2017, Vancouver Island. 2011, Abbotsford. 2013; 2015; 2016; 2016, Lower Mainland. NBSBC Bee Atlas Database: 2021, 2022; 2022; Vancouver Island; 2023, Vancouver. iNaturalist: Vancouver Island, Lower Mainland, Squamish, from 2007. Note: B. caliginosus is easily overlooked due to similarities with B. vosnesenskii. females can be differentiated from B. vosnesenskii based on the slightly but dictinctly loner malar area, and the extensive pale hairs on S4. Males can be identified gased on the same malar features, and the wider, expanded penis valves.
